choices.D: You can share custom images across tenancies and regions.
choices.B: You cannot launch a bare metal server in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Compute Service.
choices.C: You can attach a block volume in an Availability Domain other than your compute instance.
choices.A: You can launch a virtual or bare metal instance by using the same LaunchInstance API.

discussion.content: A & D are the correct options

A&D
Volumes are only accessible to instances in the same availability domain 
Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Compute lets you share custom images across tenancies and regions using image import/export.

comments.content: Block volume is AD level, so it's not possible (C)

discussion.content: Agree with A and D, but i thought C was possible. Strange

questions.question_text:
You are the Cloud Architect of a company, and are designing a solution on Oracle Cloud Infrastructure where you want to have all your compute instances resistant to hardware failure.
Which two are recommended best practices to achieve the requirement on Oracle Cloud Infrastructure? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Attach block volumes from different Availability Domains to compute instances in different Availability Domains for high availability.
choices.D: Create backups of your block volumes that are associated with compute instances in different regions.
choices.A: Create a custom image of your system drive each time you change the image.
choices.C: Design your system with redundant compute modes in different Availability Domains to support the failover capability.

discussion.content:
C is correct

You cannot configure RAC on classic IAAS

RAC is only certified/supported to run on DBaaS (Enterprise Edition â€“ Extreme Performance option) OR Exadata Cloud Service OR Database Cloud Service on VMs (OCI)

This is because the Grid Infrastructure components require both layer 2 networking and multicast, neither of which is available with OCI-C
SDN does provide multiple subnet capability but only at layer 3.
i think B is the correct answer
B is the answer as lowered license cost, bisness need

D is correct. DBCS or DBaaS is a fully managed (by Oracle) service, requiring no operation effort for the underlying database. 

A. BYOL is available on both DBaaS and OCI DB Service.
B. Makes no sense as we are comparing services and the license costs would be the same and infrastructure cost does not play to the question.
C. RAC is available on both DBaaS and OCI DB Service. OCI DB Service has a one-node or two-node RAC option for bare-metal or virtualized compute instances.
D. This option ends with compute service and not compute instance. This is the key to the answer (compute service). If you just want to build a database system without having to be concerned with database management or underlying image maintenance, this is the way to go.

In addition, DBaaS services typically give you your own Oracle instance in a virtual
machine, while the Database Cloud Service uses a multi-tenant architecture for a more scalable approach. 

https://www.oracle.com/technetwork/database/database-cloud/public/oracle-db-and-db-cloud-service-wp-1844127.pdf
Agree with b

DBCS is much expensive than the compute instance, then it will increase the cost
Thus, the right answer is C.

B is the correct answer.

questions.question_text:
You need to create a high performance shared file system service, and have been advised to use OCI File Storage Service. You have logged into the OCI
Console, created a File System in an availability domain, and followed the steps to mount the shared file system on your Oracle Linux virtual Instance. However, you are still unable to access the shared file system from your Linux instance.
What is the likely reason for this?

discussion.content: I think it's A, you need to open ingress and egress ports 111, 2048,2049 and 2050 for mount target subnet, without this mount target is not accesible. IAM is for accessing resources, not for accessing mount targets
A looks OK

comments.content: Hi Midou. Do you know if this dumps works for 1z0-1072 exam? Thanks in advance

discussion.content:
Correct Answer: A

IAM policies are needed to create, manage and delete mount targets.
Security List Rules control the ingress and egress traffic for the mount target.

Note: The question states that the shared file system and mount was already created so the IAM policies must already have been in place for that to happen.

Prerequisites
The file system must have at least one export in at least one mount target. When you create a new file system, an export for the file system is created at the same time. See Creating File Systems for more information.
Correctly configured security rules for the mount target. See Security Rules for information about how security rules work in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure. Use the instructions in Configuring VCN Security Rules for File Storage to set up security rules correctly for your file systems.
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/File/Tasks/mountingfilesystems.htm

A is one of the pre-requisites. 
Correctly configured security rules for the mount target.

https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/File/Tasks/mountingfilesystems.htm
A all day long

A is correct
 https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/iaas/Content/File/Concepts/filestorageoverview.htm
I think so , A is the answer
